example[1]: If you want to use cheese instead of chicken, that’s fine.
example[2]: ‘Do you want chili sauce on it?’ ‘No, it’s fine as it is, thanks.’
example[3]: In theory, the scheme sounds fine.
example[5]: If Scott wanted to keep his life secret, that was fine by her.
note[2]: that’s fine by me/that’s fine with me etc
example[6]: ‘How are you?’ ‘Fine, thanks, how are you?’
definition[2]: very good or of a very high standard
example[8]: Many people regard Beethoven’s fifth symphony as his finest work.
example[11]: Hatfield House is a fine example of Jacobean architecture.
example[12]: The restaurant was chosen for its good food and fine wines.
example[13]: If it’s fine tomorrow we’ll go out.
example[14]: I hope it stays fine for you.
example[15]: Fine needles are inserted in the arm.
example[19]: Her dark hair accentuates her fine features (=nose, eyes, cheeks etc).
definition[6]: fine details, changes, differences etc are very small and therefore difficult to understand or notice
example[20]: We stayed up discussing the finer points of Marxist theory.
definition[7]: in small grains, pieces, or drops
example[22]: a mixture of fine and coarse breadcrumbs
definition[8]: fine material is made so that the spaces between the threads are very small
example[24]: scarlet cloth with a very fine weave
definition[9]: used humorously to say that someone or something is bad in some way
example[25]: That’s another fine mess (=bad situation) he’s got himself into.
example[26]: You’re a fine one to talk (=you are criticizing someone for something you do yourself).
definition[10]: sounding important and impressive, but probably not true or honest
example[27]: Only time will tell whether these fine sentiments will translate into action.
definition[11]: in a way that is satisfactory or acceptable
example[30]: If I had a good job and my boyfriend stayed at home, that’d suit me fine (=be very acceptable to me).
definition[12]: if you cut something fine, you cut it into very small or very thin pieces
definition[13]: to make someone pay money as a punishment

example[35]: She was ordered to pay £150 in parking fines, plus court costs.
note[6]: pay a fine/pay £100/$50 etc in fines
example[36]: If convicted, the men face heavy fines.
definition[15]: money that someone has to pay as a punishment

example[38]: If convicted, they face heavy fines.
example[39]: The courts can still impose unlimited fines for water pollution.
example[40]: The company has been fined for illegal nuclear exports to North Korea.
definition[16]: of a very high quality or standard
